skill.name: planning-sprints
skill.description: Automatically activated when user mentions sprint planning, backlog refinement, iteration planning, sprint goals, capacity planning, velocity tracking, or asks to plan/start/close a sprint. Provides comprehensive sprint planning expertise using agile best practices.
skill.summary: Automatically activated when user mentions sprint planning, backlog refinement, iteration planning, ...
skill.author: C0ntr0lledCha0s

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only a skill definition and a template file. No executable scripts, no network calls, no credential access. All capabilities (Bash with gh CLI, Read, Write) are appropriate for sprint planning workflows.

content.value_statement: Sprint planning can feel overwhelming with competing priorities and unclear goals. This skill provides structured frameworks for backlog prioritization, velocity calculation, and capacity planning to help teams commit to achievable sprint goals.
actual_capabilities: Facilitate sprint planning sessions and define clear sprint goals
Apply prioritization frameworks like RICE, MoSCoW, and WSJF
Calculate team velocity and capacity from historical data
Create sprint plan documents using structured templates
Track sprint burndown and identify scope creep
Facilitate retrospectives and create improvement action items
limitations: Does not integrate with project management tools beyond GitHub CLI
Does not automatically update external sprint boards
Relies on gh CLI for fetching GitHub issues and project data
Scripts referenced in documentation do not exist in this skill

use_cases.title: Run effective sprint planning
use_cases.description: Structure sprint planning meetings, calculate team capacity, and commit to achievable goals using velocity data.

use_cases.title: Prioritize backlog items
use_cases.description: Apply RICE scoring and MoSCoW methods to prioritize features, bugs, and technical debt systematically.

use_cases.title: Track sprint progress
use_cases.description: Monitor burndown, identify blockers early, and make mid-sprint adjustments to stay on track.

prompt_templates.title: Plan new sprint
prompt_templates.prompt: Plan Sprint [NUMBER] for our team. We have [X] team members available for [Y] days. Our historical velocity is [Z] story points. Prioritize our backlog using RICE scoring.

prompt_templates.title: Prioritize backlog
prompt_templates.prompt: Prioritize our GitHub backlog. Fetch all open issues and apply the RICE prioritization framework to identify the top items for our next sprint.

prompt_templates.title: Check sprint status
prompt_templates.prompt: How is Sprint [NUMBER] progressing? Check our sprint burndown, identify any blockers, and suggest course corrections if we are behind schedule.

prompt_templates.title: Retrospective
prompt_templates.prompt: Help facilitate our Sprint [NUMBER] retrospective. Structure the session to identify what went well, what needs improvement, and create actionable items for next sprint.

output_examples.input: Plan Sprint 6 with 4 team members for 10 days. Our average velocity is 35 points.
output: ‚Ä¢ Sprint Goal: Complete user authentication system
‚Ä¢ Team Capacity: 4 people √ó 10 days √ó 5 hours = 200 hours
‚Ä¢ Recommended Commitment: 35 story points (based on velocity)
‚Ä¢ Sprint Board: Created in GitHub Projects

best_practices: Calculate capacity using 5-6 productive hours per day, not 8, to account for meetings and interruptions.
Use 3-5 sprint average for velocity calculations to avoid overcommitting based on anomalous sprints.
Include 20% buffer for unknowns, tech debt, and urgent bugs when committing to sprint scope.
anti_patterns: Overcommitting to more points than historical velocity supports, leading to incomplete sprints.
Skipping backlog refinement, resulting in unclear requirements during sprint planning.
Carrying over more than 30% of work to the next sprint, indicating sprints are too ambitious.

faq.question: Does this skill integrate with Jira or other project management tools?
faq.answer: No, this skill currently only integrates with GitHub via the gh CLI for fetching issues and managing project boards.

faq.question: What prioritization frameworks does this skill support?
faq.answer: It supports RICE scoring, MoSCoW method, WSJF for SAFe environments, and a simple Value vs Effort matrix.

faq.question: Can this skill create sprint boards in GitHub?
faq.answer: It delegates GitHub operations to the workflow-orchestrator agent for creating boards and organizing issues.

faq.question: Is my project data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, this skill only reads GitHub issues via gh CLI and creates local markdown files in your project directory.

faq.question: Why are the referenced scripts not available?
faq.answer: The skill documentation references scripts that were not included in this release. The skill functions using gh CLI and templates.

faq.question: How does this compare to other sprint planning tools?
faq.answer: This skill provides AI-powered guidance for planning decisions rather than a visual board. It complements tools like Jira or GitHub Projects.
